title: A Case of Chronic Neck Pain in a Sedentary Office Worker
clinical_history: Meet Emma, a 42-year-old marketing specialist who has been experiencing chronic neck pain for the past 6 months. She works as a sedentary office worker, spending most of her day sitting in front of a computer. The pain started gradually, and Emma reports that it has been worsening over time. She describes the pain as a dull ache on the right side of her neck, which sometimes radiates to her shoulder and arm. Emma has difficulty sleeping due to the pain and stiffness in her neck.

nprs.affected_area: Right cervical spine and upper trapezius muscle

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged sitting, computer work, reading, and driving. Turning her head to the right and looking up also exacerbate the pain.
picture: A 24-hour pain profile showing increased pain and stiffness in the morning and evening, with some relief during the day when she is more active.
easing_factors: Applying heat or cold packs, taking regular breaks to stretch and move around, and practicing gentle neck stretches.
past_history: Emma has a history of episodic neck pain, which she attributes to poor posture and stress. She has seen a chiropractor in the past, but the pain always returns.
medical_history: Generally healthy, but has high cholesterol and is slightly overweight.
medications: Occasionally takes ibuprofen for pain relief
personal_history: Married with two children, Emma is a busy working mom who often finds herself prioritizing work and family responsibilities over her own self-care.
imaging: X-rays of the cervical spine show mild degenerative changes and loss of lordosis.
